This is Nida, 46,a resident of Malibay, Pasay, Philippines. She is married to Leonardo, a driver, and they have children. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. She is working hard to continually provide income for her family's everyday expenses.

Nida operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a  small amount of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

She is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan to help her continue operating her business. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

Nida dreams of being a wholesaler and hopes that her children will all finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Marlynda

texts.en:
Marlynda is a 47-year-old woman from the community of Trinidad, Bohol. She is married with three children aged from 11 to 20. For fifteen years now, Marlynda and her husband have relied on farming rice and making nipa huts to support their family. 

She is asking for a loan of 11,000 PHP to buy fertilizer. Marlynda is optimistic because the loan will definitely help to sustain her business.

Part of her income will be used for her children's education. In the future, she hopes to have a better source of income and a good life for her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay his education fees.

loans.name: Renante

texts.en:
Renante is a 35-year-old man from San Miguel, Bohol in the Philippines. He is married with three children. For eight years he has been driving a habal-habal (a motorcycle with an extended seat for passengers) so as to support his family's needs. 

Renante is asking for a loan to buy spare tires, a sprocket and pay for vulcanizing of his motorcycle. He works hard because he wanted his children to have a good education. His income provide his family nutritious food and fees for school. 

In the future, he hopes to send his children to College.

loans.use: to buy spare tires, a sprocket and pay for vulcanizing.

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
This is Daisy. She previously accessed a 22,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education, in their personal, house hold and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 20,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and her children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Daisy dreams of being more successful in business and hopes that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Magsarjav

texts.en:
Mr. Magsarjav, 37 years old, lives with his wife and three children in Erdenet, the third largest city of Mongolia. He has been working as truck driver in a mining company for twelve years. His wife is a book-keeper and recently employed. Their elder son is an eleventh-grade student at high-school and his second son also goes to high-school. Their daughter just began her studies at elementary school. 

He is requesting a loan of 4,600,000 MNT to buy building materials such as fiberglass, wallpaper, vacuum insulated windows and foam. Using those materials, he wants to insulate and repair the interior parts of the house as he already renovated the outer parts using his savings. After renovation, his house will no longer lose its heat through its walls and windows and then his family will live in a comfortable and warm place without worrying about the incoming winter. Also they will burn less coal for heating thus releasing less pollutants into the air; a significant contribution to the efforts against air pollution.

loans.use: to buy building materials.

loans.name: Rith

texts.en:
Rith, aged 46, is a humble farmer residing in a small village of Baray, Kampong Thom province. She has a common-law relationship with her husband and has been blessed with three children. Rith and her husband help each other to operate and manage their own farm. To make a better living, she is also involved in a recycling business, buying and collecting recycled materials in her neighborhood and selling them to an industry for profit. She has never had any loans from other state banks or MFIs before. 

This will be her first loan and she will use it to buy a motorcycle to provide transportation for her employed child, who recently started working in Phnom Penh. She has requested a loan of 1,000 US dollar from HKL, a well-known institution providing reliable financial services. Through this purchase, she will be able to help her son have less expenses and increase his savings for his own future. She awaits your kindness and relies on your generosity.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle to provide transportation for her employed child, who works in Phnom Penh.

loans.name: Glemin Yolany

texts.es: Glemin, tiene 38 años de edad, es madre  soltera y tiene tres hijos con quienes  vive en el municipio de El Progreso, Yoro. Ella lleva 1 año de tener su mini pulpería donde  vende churros, refrescos, sal, café,  leche, cereales, golosinas entre otros etc.  Antes del negocio ella realizaba manualidades pero por necesidad de obtener más ingresos  para su familia estableció la pulpería. El préstamo que solicito es por 6,000 Lempiras y lo va invertir en la compra de productos para el negocio como refrescos, churros, leche, pan, sal, manteca y otros. Su meta es que el negocio crezca y asi poder obtener buenas ganancias para el desarrollo de la educación de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Glemin, 38, is a single mother and has three children with whom she lives in the El Progreso municipality of Yoro. She has been running her small grocery store for one year where she sells churros, fizzy drinks, salt, coffee, milk, cereals, sweets and so on. Before this business, she made handicrafts but because she needed a larger income for her family, she set up her grocery store. 

The loan that she is seeking is for 6,000 Honduran Lempiras and she will invest it in the purchase of products for the business such as fizzy drinks, churros, milk, bread, salt, butter and so on. Her objective is to see her business grow and that in this way she will obtain greater income for her children's education.

loans.use: to buy products for the business such as fizzy drinks, churros, milk, bread, salt, butter and others.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
This is Anita. She previously accessed a 20,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education, and in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 25,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result for better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Anita dreams that her business will continue to expand and hopes that her children will finish their education. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of their work every week. There, she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
This is Elizabeth, 60, a resident of Batasan, Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Ramon and is a mother to her two children. Together with her husband, she manages their household while operating her business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Elizabeth operates a meat stall. She buys meat from suppliers that deliver the meat to respective market stalls. Her products are chicken and pork. There are many patrons who prefer her products since they are assured of freshness and cleanliness. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 4000 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a 50,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional supplies of chicken and pork meat needed in her business. 

Elizabeth dreams that her business will continue to flourish and hopes to have good health. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy more chicken and pork for her business.

loans.name: Liliam Guisselly

texts.es:
Liliam es una mujer de 20 años, es soltera, vive en la ciudad de Chincha con sus padres y hermanos, ella es una persona muy trabajadora,entusiasta, que dedica todos sus esfuerzos por salir adelante; gracias a su esfuerzo y al apoyo de sus padres, Liliam pudo estudiar la carrera técnica de Computación e Informática.
Por iniciativa propia, Liliam trabaja como personal del área de recursos humanos de una empresa de su ciudad,ella trabaja todos los días por un aproximado de 10 horas y cree que le va bien por su dedicación y buen desempeño.
Liliam se encuentra muy agradecida con los prestamistas Kiva, ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada mejorara su vivienda, ya que desea pintar y poner piso de concreto a su hogar, así pues ella seguirá trabajando y esforzándose para lograr su gran sueño de tener su casa propia.
texts.en:
Liliam is a 20-year-old woman, she is single and lives in the city of Chincha with her parents and her siblings. She is a very hardworking and enthusiastic person who puts all her efforts into getting ahead in life. It is thanks to this drive and the support of her parents that Liliam was able to study a degree in Computer Sciences and Information Technology. 

At her own initiative, Liliam works as a member of staff in human resources of a company located in her city. She works every day for approximately ten hours and believes that it is going well thanks to her dedication and hard work. 

Liliam is very grateful to the Kiva loan lenders as it is thanks to the help given she will improve her home as she wants to paint and lay down a concrete floor in her home, in doing so, she will continue to work and make an effort to achieve her greatest dream of having her own home.

loans.use: to improve her home.

loans.name: Rafaela

texts.en:
This is Rafaela, 32, a resident of Malibay, Pasay, Philippines. She is married to Glen, a painter and she is a mother to their children. Together with her husband, she manages their household while operating the business. She and her husband are working hard to provide income for their everyday needs.

Rafaela maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. The dealer's prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are investing in as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 2,000 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional supplies and merchandise products like shampoo, cologne, deodorant, perfume, soap, fabric softener, undergarments and other products needed in her business.

Rafaela hopes to become successful in her business and dreams of giving her children a good life and education. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional supplies and merchandise products like clothing, footwear, undergarments, and cosmetics needed in her business.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda is a 38-year-old woman from the town of Bien Unido, Bohol. She is married with three children. For eight years now, she has been into farming seaweed, selling clothes, chips and home-cooked snacks. 

Merlinda is asking for a loan to be used as an additional capital to buy more chips and clothing that she can sell in the neighborhood. Any profit will be used for her family's healthy diet and school fees. 

In the future, she hopes to live an abundant life as a result of her businesses.

loans.use: to buy chips and clothing.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
This is Francisca. She previously accessed a 35,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 35,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Francisca hopes that her variety store will become bigger and dreams of having a happy family. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week. She also draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Naranbaatar

texts.en:
Naranbaatar, aged 33, lives with his wife and two children in Ulaanbaatar, capital city of Mongolia. His family resides in a house on a plot of land. He has been providing a taxi service to local people since 2000. Recently, Naranbaatar began to work as an assistant carpenter in a factory and in his non-work time, he provides the taxi service. His wife works as a nurse in a hospital. Their son goes to high school and their daughter is in kindergarten. 

Naranbaatar is requesting a loan of 1,500,000 MNT to purchase fiberglass and foam in order to insulate his house. As winter comes closer in Mongolia, the family needs to insulate their house so that they can live in a comfortable and warm place. Also, they will burn less coal for heating thus releasing less pollutants into the atmosphere.

(In the above photo, you can see Naranbaatar's old house and the car which he uses for the taxi service.)

loans.use: to purchase fiberglass and foam

loans.name: Sari Madu Group

texts.en:
Ni Luh is a 26-year-old housewife who has been running a pig-breeding business since she married. She has a toddler, four years old. As the head of the Sari Madu group, she’s responsible for the group loan and payment. 

Now the 14 members are receiving their new loan, a total 22,5M IDR, 1,5M IDR each.
 
Ni Luh will use her loan to purchase three piglets and feed. Ni Luh hopes the cooperation between the group and MUK goes well and MUK will support them until the group is able to be independent in terms of capital.

loans.use: to purchase three piglets and feed.

loans.name: Segundina

texts.en:
This is Segundina, 58, a resident of Malibay, Pasay, Philippines. She is a widow and she has four children. She and her children manage their household while operating the business. She is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Segundina operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

She is requesting a PHP 12,000 loan to help her continue in the operation of her business. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

Segundina hopes to have a grocery store and dreams of having good health.  She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Faustina Mena Ekua

texts.en: After graduating from junior high school, Faustina Mena Ekua decided to set up her own baking shop business in Mpeasem (near Cape Coast). With over two years of experience, she is currently looking to expand her enterprise further. Unfortunately, she is limited due to a lack of funding. As a result, this loan will be used to help her to purchase more flour to produce more bread for sale. She aims at using the profits from her business to help support her husband (who is a driver) with the upkeep of their house, whilst ensuring that their children are able to experience a better life.

loans.use: to help her by purchase more flour to produce more bread for sale.

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn, aged 36, is a resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Philippines. Her partner's name is Joey and she has two children. She and her partner manage their household while operating the business. She works hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Analyn operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Analyn earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

Analyn is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan to help her continue operating her business. She will use the loan to buy grocery items, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

Analyn dreams of expanding her business and hopes to have a better life for her family.  She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God that she studies there.

All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy grocery items, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma is married with four school-age children. She is 44 years old and lives in Gabayan, Lazi, Siquijor. Alma sells a variety of products to earn a living and has had this business for one year. Each month, she earns PHP 6,000 doing this type of work. 

Alma has requested a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 to be used to buy canned goods, noodles, beverages and soft drinks to sell. She is a new member of PMPC. In the future, Alma hopes to expand her business with the help of this institution.

loans.use: To buy canned goods, noodles, beverages and soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Rogaciano

texts.en:
Rogaciano is a 43-year-old man, married with five children. His eldest child is 12 and the youngest is three. Rogaciano works driving a habal-habal (motorcycle with extended seat for passengers) in his town of Trinidad, Bohol. He has also worked as a heavy equipment operator for four years, earning 4,000 PHP per month.

Rogaciano is asking for a loan to pay school fees. He is confident that while working, he can better sustain his children's needs through the loan. In the future, he hopes to send all his children to school so they can have a better future.

loans.use: to pay school fees

loans.name: Zurab

texts.en:
Zurab is a 49-year-old married man who lives in a small town of Gori district with his wife and two school-aged children. Zurab is the only one who makes money in his household.  Specifically, he is employed by a private auto company and provides the organization with the technical materials. His small wage is hardly enough to cover food and everyday expenses. That is why Zurab decided to start his own business. All of the financial institutions rejected his loan requests because of his lack of experience in the business. 

After several unsuccessful attempts, Zurab applied for credit to MFO Credo. His request was approved in the framework of a Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva. This program enables the vulnerable poor to start or re-start businesses. A loan of $2,000 will help him to purchase a minibus. Once the minibus is purchased, he will transport passengers on the minibus line in return for a service fee. This will significantly increase the family income. 

With the increased income, he will be able to improve the living conditions of his family members.

loans.use: to purchase a mini-bus and transport passengers inter town.

loans.name: Manuela Margarita

texts.es:
En Los Bajos de Montecristi, ciudad conocida por su diversidad de productos típicos, como por ejemplo los sombreros de paja toquillas conocidos dentro y fuera del país se reúnen cada 15  días las socias del Banco Comunal La Dolorosa Del Pechiche.

Aquí vive la señora Manuela, tiene 55 años  de edad, es madre soltera de un hijo el mismo que ya es mayor de edad e independiente.  

Doña Manuela es una mujer que a pesar de sus edad le gusta valerse por sí misma y obtener sus propios ingresos, ella en sociedad con su hijo tienen una fábrica de ladrillos (material utilizado en la construcción de viviendas), allí su hijo trabaja junto con dos ayudantes se encargan de fabricar los ladrillos los mismos que luego entregan a comerciantes que llegan hasta el sitio para luego llevarlos a los distintos lugares donde los comercializan, ella les ayuda realizando los cobros de lo que venden y les lleva la comida al lugar donde ellos laboran, llevan más de 15 años en esta labor y les va muy bien y es así como ellos pueden salir adelante.

Este crédito es para comprar leña, aserrín y palmito que son los materiales que emplean para elaborar estos productos. Lleva 8 años en el Banco Comunal y le gusta por la ayuda que le dan con los créditos. 

Su sueño es tener un carro para llevar sus productos directamente a las construcciones.
texts.en:
In Los Bajos de Montecristi, a city known for the diversity of its typical products such as the straw hats famous both within and outside of the country, the members of the La Dolorosa Del Pechiche communal bank meet every day. This is where Manuela lives, she is 55 years old, she is a single mother to a son who is now an adult and is independent. 

Manuela is a woman who, despite her age, likes to be self-sufficient and earn her own income. Along with her son, she owns a brick factory (material used to build homes), which is where her son works together with two assistants. They are responsible for making the bricks which they then deliver to trades who come to the site in order to then transport them to the different areas in which they are sold. Manuela helps them by collecting what they sell and brings them food where they work. They have been doing this work for 15 years now and it is going very well, this is how they are getting ahead in life.

This loan is to buy firewood, sawdust and palm fibers which are the materials used to make these products. Manuela has been part of the communal bank for 8 years and she likes it for the help given with the loans.

Her dream is to have a vehicle to carry the products directly to the construction sites.

loans.use: to buy firewood, sawdust and y palm fibers.

loans.name: Pedrito

texts.en:
Pedrito, aged 61, is married and is from Lower Lamac, Oroquieta City. He loves flower gardening and sells flowers for a living. Being a member of PMPC, he has applied for several loan cycles and has remained a member in good standing. 

Pedrito has now applied for a loan to purchase a greater variety of ornaments to sell. He is confident that with more variety to sell, this would mean additional income. He hopes to save more for his retirement and for family emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase a greater variety of ornaments to sell

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie is 31 years old, married and lives in Lower Lamac, Oroquieta City. She works with her husband and earns an income through supporting him in providing auto shop services. 

Elsie and her husband admire the products and services of PMPC and they have taken out a loan to purchase a welding machine. The unit will help them to increase their income as they will be able to provide welding services. Elsie hopes to remain a member in good standing with the cooperative.

loans.use: to purchase a welding machine

location.town: Oroquieta-Lower Lamac, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occ

loans.name: Rentsendorj

texts.en:
Rentsendorj, aged 31, lives with his wife and two-year-old daughter in Ulaanbaatar, capital city of Mongolia. The family resides in a traditional Mongolian ger (a portable felt dwelling) on a plot of land. His wife stays at home looking after their daughter. Rentsendorj has been transporting goods between districts using his own truck and finds his clients at outdoor markets. 

As one person's income can't provide for the needs of three people, he has decided to sell vegetables at markets after buying them from farmers in the countryside. Rentsendorj is therefore requesting a loan of 2,000,000 MNT to purchase large amounts of vegetables at a lower price. He is a very hard-working individual who is researching every way through which to generate income for his wife and little daughter.

loans.use: to purchase large amounts of vegetables

loans.name: Kov

texts.en:
Kov, aged 34, is a hard-working woman who has been involved in three businesses: farming followed by fish selling and pig fattening businesses. She works tirelessly to promote a moderate living standard and to provide her three children with quality of life. With the income earned from her business activities, she covers her daily costs such as food, household bills and other allowances needed to support her children at school. In the same manner, Kov’s husband supports his family through his dedication to fishing and transportation businesses.

As of now, Kov has applied for a loan amounting to USD300 through HKL's branch office to purchase a trailer which will be attached to her husband’s motorcycle to provide transportation services.
 
She hopes that, through this investment, her husband will be able to earn additional income to sustain her family's living standard. Kov thanks lenders for their support. She awaits your kindness and relies on your generosity.

loans.use: to purchase a trailer to attach to her husband’s motorcycle to provide transportation services.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a catering services business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for five years. Rosemarie earns additional income from buying and selling charcoal and coconuts.

She is borrowing PHP 22,000 through NWTF to purchase additional ingredients and utensils for her catering services business. Rosemarie has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients and utensils for her business

loans.name: Celia

texts.es: Celia tiene 31 años de edad y vive en la hermosa ciudad de Patria junto con su pareja y sus dos hijos, ella es una persona emprendedora y trabajadora que sale adelante con mucho esfuerzo y dedicación pues su actividad económica principal es la agricultura entonces cosecha hojas de coca y la venta de animales menores como gallinas y en sus horas libres se dedica a la venta de refrescos. Ya son varios años que se dedica a este negocio y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. Ella pertenece al banco comunal “Señor de Huanca de Patria” y esta oportunidad requiere el préstamo para comprar gallinas y así aumentar su capital de trabajo en este rubro. Agradece y valora el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas mensuales con mucha responsabilidad. (El poblado de Patria se destaca por el comercio de productos de la selva, así como servicios de alojamiento y restaurantes. Patria es una ciudad de ingreso al Parque Nacional del Manu.)
texts.en:
Celia, 31, lives with her sister, husband, and two children in Patria. She is enterprising and works hard to get ahead. Her main economic activity is farming. She harvests coca leaves and raises farmyard animals such as hens, and, in her spare time, she sells beverages. She has been doing this for some years, and her efforts are paying off.

Celia belongs to the communal bank “Señor de Huanca de Patria” and has applied for a loan to buy hens and increase working capital. She is grateful for and appreciates the loan and promises to make her monthly payments on time. The town of Patria offers products from the rainforest, lodging, and restaurants and sits at the entrance to Manu National Park.

loans.use: to buy hens.

loans.name: Maylen

texts.en:
Maylen, aged 33, is a resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Philippines. Her partner's name is Evaristo and she has three children. She and her partner manage their household while operating the business. She works hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Maylen operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

Maylen is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan to help her continue operating her business. She will use the loan to buy grocery items, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

Maylen hopes that her business will continue to grow and dreams of having a good and peaceful life.  She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God that she studies there.

All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy grocery items, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Mely

texts.en:
Mely is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a food vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 10,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase ingredients like rice, coconut, sugar, etc., for her food vending business. Mely has been in this business for 3 years. She earns more income from a general store.

Mely has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients like rice, coconut, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Simon

texts.es: Simon tiene 39 años de edad y vive en la hermosa ciudad de Patria junto con su pareja y tiene un hijo, él es una persona emprendedora y trabajadora que sale adelante con mucho esfuerzo y dedicación pues su actividad económica principal es la agricultura pues cosecha platanos, arroz, hoja de coca. Ya son varios años que se dedica a este negocio y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo, él pertenece al banco comunal “Señor de Huanca de Patria” y esta oportunidad requiere el préstamo para comprar semillas y abono y así aumentar su capital de trabajo en este rubro. Agradece y valora el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas mensuales con mucha responsabilidad. (El poblado de Patria se destaca por el comercio de productos de la selva, así como servicios de alojamiento y restaurantes. Patria es una ciudad de ingreso al Parque Nacional del Manu.)
texts.en: Simon is 39 years old and lives in the beautiful city of Patria with his partner and son.  Simon is very enterprising and hard-working and is prospering with a lot of effort and dedication.  His main work is in agriculture - he grows plantains, rice and coca plants.  He has been working in this business for several years and it is going well thanks to his determination.  Simon is part of the "Señor de Huanca de Patria" communal bank and on this occasion needs a loan in order to buy seeds and manure, thus allowing him to increase his working capital.  Simon is grateful for and understands the value of this loan and promises to be responsible with his monthly repayments.  (The town of Patria is known for its jungle products, as well as its accommodation services and restaurants.  Patria is inside the Manu National Park).

loans.use: to buy seeds and manure.

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma is 47 years old and married with three children who are in school.

Elma works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy additional stocks of bread, soap, spices, eggs, etc., to sell.

Elma has borrowed and repaid 6 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 5 years and also earns an income from food vending.

Elma aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of bread, soap, spices, eggs, etc., to sell

loans.name: Tres Hermanos Group

texts.es: Los Tres Hermanos es un grupo familia está conformado por Doña Marcela, Fernando El es hermano de Doña Marcela y Don Rafael quien es el esposo de Doña Marcela pero en la comunidad creen que ellos son hermanos decidieron ponerle así porque siempre están juntos, se consideran unos aventureros tienen mucha comunicación entre ellos se ayudan mutuamente. Ellos viven en una comunidad pequeña pero muy tranquila el trasporte anteriormente era muy escaso ahora ya circulan mas taxis. Doña Marce quien es la representante del grupo tiene 40 años de edad está casada desde hace 18 años juntos han formado una familia con tres niños los cuales aun dependen de dicha pareja y se encuentran estudiando. Doña Marce es una mujer muy trabajadora muy emprendedora al mismo tiempo atiende tres negocios su cocina económica, una tienda de abarrotes y la venta de su ropa el negocio lo inicio porque su mamá le regalo ropa y fue la que puso a la venta lleva ya 15 años en el negocio esta los días miércoles, jueves, viernes y sábados, La tienda de abarrotes esta los días Domingos, Lunes, Martes,  en el negocio lleva ya cuatro años “Quise iniciar otra actividad nueva para aumentar mis ganancias un poco y asi ayudar con los gastos del hogar” Su puesto de abarrotes los pone en los mercados en las plazas. “Con mi cocina económica llevo ya cuatro años inicie vendiendo tortas, tacos y pambazos, pero como a los clientes les gusto el sazón me motivaron a iniciar con una cocina económica para poder ofrecerles comidas corridas” Doña Marce todos los días abre su cocina económica mientras ella trabaja en sus otros dos negocios la cocina económica la atienden sus empleadas, Don Rafael también tiene su propio negocio la venta de ropa para eso está solicitando el crédito para comprar más ropa. Los negocios de Doña Marce van muy bien aunque su única dificultad fue con la cocina económica porque tiene varias competencias “Creo que mi cocina económica es diferente a las demás por el buen sazón y por el agua de frutas el cual es 100% natural” Anteriormente estaba en otro local pero los dueños le pidieron el local porque ellos se quedaron con la cocina económica, Doña Marce se cambio de local ahí los dueños fueron muy amables con ella le acondicionaron su cocina muy bien ella dice que corrió con mucha suerte, Aunque su negocio está bien escondido las personas ya saben en donde llegar para comer la mejor comida. El Sueño de Doña Marce es progresar mas en sus negocios y poder abrir otra cocina económica sonriendo Ella comento “Se llamaría Cocina Maricela 2” la que tiene ahora se llama Cocina Maricela si logra abrir su cocina dejaría completamente sus otros dos negocios para dedicarse solo a sus cocinas económicas.  “Para mis hijos me gustaría verlos realizados profesionalmente, para nada me gustaría que se dedicaran al comercio es un trabajo muy duro mi hija está estudiando la secundaria pero si tiene muchas ganas de  estudiar una carrera profesional yo apoyare en todo para ver su sueño realizado” Fernando apoya mucho a Doña Marce en sus negocios pero el invertirá en artículos electrodomésticos.
texts.en:
The members of the communal bank Three Brothers are: Marcela, Fernando, Marcela's brother; and Rafael, Marcela's husband. The men are considered brothers by the community because they are always together doing things, talking, and helping one another. They live in a small, quiet town, where transportation used to be a problem, but taxis are now readily available.

Marce, 40, represents the group and has been married for 18 years. She has three dependent children who are in school. Marce is hardworking and enterprising. She has three businesses: a diner, a small grocery shop, and selling clothing. She started selling clothing when her mother gave her clothing as a gift 15 years ago, and she works at this job Wednesday through Saturday. She has been managing her grocery store Sunday through Tuesday for four years.  “I wanted to start another business to increase my income and help pay household expenses.” Her grocery shop is in one of the local markets. “I started selling sandwiches and tacos four years ago, but my customers liked my recipes so much that I decided to open a diner to offer more items.” Marce's diner is open every day and is managed by her employees while she is at her other two businesses. 

Rafael also sells clothing and has applied for a loan to buy more. Marce's businesses are successful, though her diner has competition. “I think my diner stands out because the food is delicious, and the juices are 100% natural.” The owners of her prior location asked her to move, as they wanted to run the diner. Marce moved to a space where the owners are very nice, and she was able to put in air conditioning. She says she is very lucky. The new location is less visible, but customers know where to find the best food. 

Marce dreams of growing her businesses and opening another diner. She smiles and says, “I will name it Maricela 2.” Her current diner is called Cocina Maricela. If she is able to open a second diner, she will give up her other businesses to concentrate on selling food. “I want my children to become professionals rather than becoming merchants, which is a very hard trade. My daughter is in middle school, and she wants very much to study for a career. I will support her in every way so that she can achieve her dream.” Fernando supports Marce's businesses, but he will invest in household appliances.

loans.use: to buy groceries such as bread, eggs, milk, sugar, etc.

location.town: Santa Cruz Mextepec, San Felipe del Progreso

loans.name: Inés Virginia

texts.es:
En Los Bajos de Montecristi, ciudad conocida por su gran diversidad de productos típicos, como por ejemplo los sombreros de paja toquillas conocidos dentro y fuera del país se reúnen cada 15  días las socias del Banco Comunal La Dolorosa Del Pechiche.

En este lugar vive la señora Inés, tiene 34 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen cuatro hijos de  18, 15, 12 y 8 años, los tres mayores estudian en colegio y el menor en escuela. Su esposo es artesano.

Doña Inés trabaja en una fábrica en la ciudad de Manta, ella realiza el crédito  para ayudarle a su esposo y que pueda sacar adelante su negocio, él tiene una pequeña fábrica de ladrillos (material utilizado en la construcción de viviendas), en este lugar él  con el papá de ella se encargan de elaborar y vender los ladrillos, ellos le entregan sus productos a comerciantes que llegan hasta su fabrica para luego llevarlos a distintos lugares donde venden estos productos, llevan más de 10 años dedicados a esta actividad la misma que le deja muy buenas satisfacciones.

Este crédito es para comprar leña, aserrín, agua y palmito que son los materiales que emplean para elaborar los ladrillos. Lleva 6 años en el Banco Comunal y le gusta por la ayuda que le brindan los créditos. 

Sus sueños seguir adelante y que sus hijos tengan una muy buena educación.
texts.en:
In Los Bajos de Montecristi, a city known for its diverse typical products, such as the straw hats that are known nationally and internationally, the members of the "La Dolorosa del Pechciche" communal bank meet every fortnight.

It is here that 34-year-old Inés lives.  She is married and, with her husband, has four children, aged 18, 15, 12, and 8 years old respectively.  The three oldest are in high school while the youngest is in primary school.  Inés' husband is a craftsman.

Inés works in a factory in the city of Manta.  She is applying for a loan to help her husband to further his business.  Her husband has a small factory where he makes bricks (which are used to build houses).  In the factory, Inés' husband works with Inés' father to make and sell bricks.  They sell their products to businessmen who come to the factory to take them to different places to sell on.  They have been doing this work for over ten years and they are very satisfied with it.

This loan will be used to buy firewood, sawdust, water and palm heart, all materials that they use to make the bricks.  Inés has been with the communal bank for six years and she likes it because of the help that is provided through loans.

Inés' dreams are to get ahead in life and for her children to have very good education.

loans.use: to buy firewood, sawdust, water, and heart of palm.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
This is Teresita, 56, a resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Philippines. Her partner is Arturo, a foreman, and they have children. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. She is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Teresita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5-PHPs worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

She is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan to help her continue in the operation of her business. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

Teresita dreams to expand her business and hopes to be always happy.  She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week, and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business

loans.name: Gigi

texts.en:
As a married parent of seven children, five of whom are in school, Gigi works hard to support her family.

She has a business buying and selling nipa roofing (thatched roofing made from the leaves of the Nipa palm) in the Philippines. Gigi is borrowing 10,000 PHP through NWTF for her business buying and selling nipa roofing.

Gigi has been sustaining her business activities through her past 3 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock to sell

loans.name: Yos

texts.en:
Yos is 37 years old and lives with her husband and five children in a traditional house made from farm leaves located in Kampong Thom province.

Yos works on a small farm for a living but it doesn't provide enough to feed her family, so she also helps her husband manage a recycling business to sustain their living standard. She is a hardworking woman and is responsible about her work. She has been in this type of business for about 9 years, earning a gross profit of 10,000 KHR per day.

Yos is soliciting a loan to improve the supports for her recycling business. She will use this loan to buy a motorcycle, which will allow her husband to collect recycling materials in far distant areas. In this manner, she hopes to generate greater income for her home and, thus, be able to offer her family a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle to support her recycling business

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
En Los Bajos de Montecristi, ciudad conocida por su gran diversidad de productos típicos, como por ejemplo los sombreros de paja toquillas conocidos dentro y fuera del país se reúnen cada 15  días las socias del Banco Comunal La Dolorosa Del Pechiche.

En este lugar vive la señora Juana, tiene 44 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene 7 hijos, 6 de los cuales ya son mayores de edad, el menor tiene 10 años y estudia  en  escuela, los dos menores aun viven en su casa. Su esposo  se dedica al comercio y la agricultura.

Doña Juana es una mujer muy luchadora que le gusta trabajar para ayudarle a su marido a salir adelante,  el crédito lo divide para su negocio y el de su marido, el cual se dedica a recorrer por la localidad en un triciclo vendiendo  verduras y legumbre, y ella por las tardes vende carne y cueritos asados acompañados de platino asado lo cual es el deleite de sus clientes que a diario visitan su casa, ella lleva 5 años dedicada a esto mientras que su marido muchos más. Con estos negocios es como ellos pueden salir adelante. 

Este crédito es para comprar legumbres, verduras, carne, plátanos y otros víveres que ella utiliza para preparar sus platos. Es socia fundadora del Banco comunal y le gusta porque con los créditos su familia ha podido salir adelante.

Su sueño es tener buena salud.
texts.en:
In Los Bajos de Montecristi, a city known for its diverse typical products, such as the straw hats that are known nationally and internationally, the members of the "La Dolorosa del Pechciche" communal bank meet every fortnight.

It is here that 44-year-old Juana lives.  She is married and, with her husband, has seven children, six of whom are now independent adults.  The youngest is ten years old and is in primary school.  The two youngest still live at home.  Juana's husband is a businessman and works in farming.

Juana is a feisty woman who likes to work to help her husband to get ahead.  This loan will be split between Juana's business, and her husband's business. Juana's husband makes a living going around the city on a tricycle, selling vegetables and pulses.  In the afternoon, Juana sells roasted meat with plantain. This meal is a much liked by Juana's customers who come to her house every day to eat it.  She has been doing this work for five years and her husband has been doing his for much longer.  It is with these businesses that the couple are able to get ahead.

This loan will be used to buy vegetables, pulses, meat, plantains, and other supplies that Juana needs to make her dishes.  Juana is a founding member of the communal bank and she likes it because, with the loans, the family has been able to prosper.

Juana's dream is to keep up her good health.

loans.use: to buy vegetables, pulses, meat, plantains, and other supplies.

loans.name: Esmeralda

texts.es: La señora Esmeralda, tiene 46 años de edad, esta casada, vive en el municipio de Santa Rita, El Progreso, Yoro junto a una hija y una nieta.  Anteriormente impartía clases como  maestra de educación primaria. Hace  10 años que se  dedica a la venta de productos plásticos (tinas, jarrones, vasos, platos, pelotas, lazos, coladores etc.)  También vende mercadería como ropa  de temporada. El préstamo que solicita es por 25,000 Lempiras con el cual va comprar mercadería nueva de temporada como ropa, zapatos, calcetas, plasticos y otros para aprovechar la temporada de las fiestas patria s. Su meta es crecer con el negocio en el mercado y generar muy buenos ingresos.
texts.en:
Esmeralda, 46, is married and lives in Santa Rita, El Progreso, Yoro, with her daughter and granddaughter. She used to be an elementary school teacher. Ten years ago, she started selling plastic items (basins, jars, glasses, plates, balls, ribbons, colanders, etc.). She also sells seasonal clothing.

She will use this loan of 25,000 lempiras to buy seasonal clothing, footwear, and socks and plastic containers to take advantage of the national holidays. Her goal is to grow her business and generate a good income.

loans.use: to buy seasonal clothing, footwear, and socks and plastic containers to sell.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.es: El Sr. Samuel tiene 26 años y es casado con dos hijos de las edades de 5 y 10 años,  el se dedica al  servicio de arreglo de autos y frenos para movilidades en su taller que se encuentra en la localidad de el Torno,  este préstamo es su primera secuencia dentro de la institución,  El Sr. Samuel va a usar este préstamo para la compra de un aprensa hidráulica, la   razón para solicitar este préstamo es que  quiere mejorar su negocio, El Sr. Samuel enfrenta retos en su negocio que son la competencia ya que existen muchas tiendas con la misma actividad  va a utilizar los beneficios en seguir comprando lo que necesita para equipar su taller, su deseo es tener un negocio estable y rentable y de esta manera genera más ingresos y por ende mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en: Samuel is 26 years old. He is married and has two children, aged 5 and 10. He works repairing cars and brakes in his workshop located in the town of El Torno. This loan is his first cycle with the institution. Samuel is going to use this loan to buy a hydraulic press. The reason for asking for this loan is that he wants to improve his business. Samuel faces challenges in his business such as competition, because there are a lot of places doing the same thing. He is going to use the profits to keep buying what he needs to outfit his workshop. He wants to have a stable and profitable business so he can generate more income and improve his quality of life.

loans.use: to buy a hydraulic press.

loans.name: Nieve Piedad

texts.es:
En Los Bajos de Montecristi, ciudad conocida por su gran diversidad de productos típicos, como por ejemplo los sombreros de paja toquillas conocidos dentro y fuera del país se reúnen cada 15  días las socias del Banco Comunal La Dolorosa Del Pechiche.

En este lugar vive la señora Nieve, tiene 73 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene 7 hijos mayores de edad, en su casa aun viven 3 de ellos que aun están solteros. Su esposo  está enfermo y ya no trabaja.

Doña Nieve realiza el crédito para el negocio familiar, su esposo tenía una ladrillera pero por motivos de enfermedad ahora su hijo se hace cargo de él, es por eso que ella realiza el crédito ya que ahora ellos trabajan en sociedad, su hijo  se encarga de elaboración de los ladrillos y ella en su casa de las ventas, ya que hasta su casa llegan los comerciantes que luego se encargan de llevarlos a otros lugares a entregar, trabajan de lunes a viernes desde las 8h00 hasta las 18h00 y llevan dedicados a esta actividad por más de 40 años.

Este crédito es para comprar leña, aserrín, agua y palmito que son los materiales que emplean para elaborar los ladrillos. Es socia fundadora del Banco comunal le gusta porque los créditos han sido una bendición para ella.

Sus sueños son seguir y tener fuerzas para continuar trabajando.
texts.en:
Every two weeks, the members of the communal bank "La Dolorosa Del Pechiche" meet in Los Bajos de Montecristi, a city known nationwide for a wide range of products such as fine straw hats. Nieve, 73, lives here, is married, and has seven grown children, three of whom are single and still live at home. Her husband is ill and doesn't work.

Nieve has applied for a loan for the family business. Her husband has a brick shop, which her son manages due to her husband's illness. She is asking for a loan, as the family is working together. Her son is in charge of making the bricks, while she sells to merchants who come to her house to buy the bricks and deliver them to other places. They work Monday through Friday from 8 a.m. until 6 p.m. They have operated this business for more than 40 years.

The loan will buy wood, sawdust, water, and palm heart, which are the materials used in making bricks. She likes being part of the communal bank because the loans have been a blessing. She dreams of being able to continue working.

loans.use: to buy wood, sawdust, water, and palm heart.

loans.name: Mariana

texts.es:
En Los Bajos de Montecristi, ciudad conocida por su gran diversidad de productos típicos, como por ejemplo los sombreros de paja toquillas conocidos dentro y fuera del país se reúnen cada 15  días las socias del Banco Comunal La Dolorosa Del Pechiche.

En este lugar  vive la señora Mariana, tiene 52 años  de edad, está casada y fruto de esta relación tiene 7 hijos mayores de edad e independientes. Su esposo es taxista.

Doña Mariana es una mujer muy activa que le gusta trabajar para ganar algo por su cuenta y no depender de su marido, ella se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo, su forma de  venta es puerta a puerta, aunque  la mayor parte de su mercadería es para entregar ya que tiene muchos pedidos que sus clientes le  realizan con anticipación, ella deja a crédito a sus clientes  y cobra en dos o tres pagos. Ella lleva más de 12 años que se dedica a esta actividad y le va muy bien.

Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar más mercadería como: pantalones, blusas, camisetas y ropa de niños.

Sus sueños es seguir adelante y gozar de buena salud.
texts.en:
In Los Bajos de Montecristi, a city known for its great diversity of traditional products such as the paja toquilla hats known in and out of the country, the members of the La Dolorosa Del Pechiche communal bank meet every two weeks.

Here lives Mariana. She is 52, married and from her marriage has 7 grown children who are on their own. Her husband is a taxi driver. 

Mariana is a very active woman who likes to earn something on her own and to depend on her husband. She sells all types of clothing door to door, although most of the time she is delivering the clothes because she gets a lot of orders ahead of time from her customers. She sells on credit and collects in two or three payments. She has been doing this activity for more than 12 years and it is going well for her. 

She is going to use this loan to buy more merchandise such as: pants, blouses, t-shirts and children's clothing. 

Her dreams are to keep going forward and have good health.

loans.use: to buy pants, blouses, t-shirts and children's clothes.

loans.name: Toborochi Group

texts.es: El Banco de emprendimiento TOBOROCHI,  Está  compuesto por ocho integrantes siete mujeres y un varón,  la presidenta del banco es la Sra. Moira, ella tiene un hijo de la edad de cuatro años, ella se dedica a la venta de calzados de manera ambulante, visitando distintas ferias y mercados de la ciudad de Santa Cruz,  este préstamo es su primera secuencia dentro de la institución, la Sra. Moira va a utilizar este préstamo para la compra de calzados por mayor   y así de esta manera brindar variedad de sus productos  a  sus clientes e incrementar sus ganancias ya que esta época tiene mucha demanda,  su razón para solicitar este préstamo es seguir mejorando en su  negocio, la Sra. Moira va a utilizar los beneficios para seguir comprando variedad de productos, la Sra. Moira es una persona muy trabajadora se siente feliz por la oportunidad brindada ya que esta es la única fuente de ingresos con la que cuenta.
texts.en:
The communal bank Toborochi comprises eight members, three women and a man. The group's president, Moira, has a four-year-old son. She is a footwear street vendor, who travels to various fairs and markets in the city of Santa Cruz. 

This is her first loan cycle with the institution. She will use the funding to buy wholesale footwear so that she can offer her customers more variety and increase her income while seasonal demand is strong. She has applied for a loan to keep growing her business, and Moira will invest her profits in more merchandise. Moira works hard and is pleased with this opportunity, as this business is her only source of income.

loans.use: to buy wholesale footwear.

loans.name: Adelfa Alcira

texts.es: La Sra. Adelfa tiene 23 años, casada con un hijo pequeño,  ella se dedica a la venta de ropa según la temporada y también zapatos,  ella vende sus productos en su puesto de venta que se encuentra en la zona  24 de septiembre de la ciudad de Santa Cruz,  este préstamo es su  primera secuencia dentro de la institución, la Sra. Adelfa va a usar este préstamo para la compra de ropa por mayor como blusas y poleras  para surtir su negocio ya que se acerca la época de calor, y esta época tiene mucha venta e incluso pedidos , su razón para solicitar este préstamo es falta de capital, la Sra. Adelfa enfrenta retos en su negocio que son la competencia diaria, va a utilizar los beneficios en comprar variedad de ropa, su deseo para su negocio tener mercadería surtida para ofrecer variedad de productos a su clientes, la Sra. Adelfa se siente feliz y agradecida con la institución por el apoyo brindado ya que le permite mejorar en su negocio.
texts.en: Adelfa is 23 years old. She is married and has a small child. She sells seasonal clothing and shoes. She sells her products from her sales spot in the 24 de Septiembre area in the city of Santa Cruz. This loan is her first cycle within the institution. Adelfa is going to use this loan to buy clothes wholesale, such as blouses and polo shirts, in order to stock her business, since the warm weather is coming and she has a lot of sales, including orders. Her reason for asking for this loan is a lack of capital. Adelfa faces challenges in her business, such as the daily competition. She is going to use the profits to buy a variety of clothing. She wants her business to have merchandise stocked to offer a variety of products to her customers. Adelfa is happy and grateful to the institution for the support offered that will allow her to improve in her business.

loans.use: to buy clothes wholesale, such as blouses and polo shirts.

loans.name: Luzminda

texts.en:
Luzminda is a constant help to her husband in providing for the family. At the age of 51, she has kept her little clothing shop full of stock to sell. She is attracted to the various programs and services of PMPC and has availed herself of the insurance, savings and loans services. 

Now, she is asking for a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase additional ready-to-wear inventory to sell. She wants to save more for their children's education.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory to sell.

location.town: Oroquieta-Lower Lamac, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occ

loans.name: Rovegen

texts.en:
Rovegen is 24 years old and is from Trinidad, Bohol. She is married with a baby girl who is eight months old. Her husband is a government employee. For a year now, while he works, she farms rice to help augment the income of her family. She is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer for her farm and expand the land that she cultivates.

Her loan will be a great help so she can sustain her business and the needs of her child. 

In the future, she hopes to have other business options to increase profitability and educate her children.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Alcan

texts.en:
Alcan is 57 years old. He has a big family and he is father of seven children. He is a farmer and has been raising seasonal fruits and vegetables for the last 20 years. During these years, Alcan gained enough skills and experience to run the business. He chose this crop business because it is profitable and fresh fruits and vegetables are in high demand. 

People use fresh vegetables every day and consider them healthy. Many national dishes are made of vegetables, like pilau and dolma. Fresh fruits are served on every table in Azerbaijan and families also make a fresh punch. He usually sells his crop in the central bazaar. His monthly income is 140 AZN.

As these products are in high demand, Alcan wants to expand his business and produce more fruits and vegetables to meet market demand. For this purpose he applied for a loan of 2,000 AZN. He will buy new garden tools, seeds and fertilizers. This will be his seventh loan and he has a good client history.

loans.use: to buy new garden tools, seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Ma. Luisa

texts.en:
Ma. Luisa is 31 years old, married with one child who is in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. 

Ma. Luisa has a business buying and selling sea shells in the Philippines. Ma. Luisa requested a PHP 5,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional shells to sell.

Ma. Luisa has been in this business for one year. In the future, Ma. Luisa would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional shells to sell.

loans.name: Junith

texts.en:
Junith is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fish vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to buy additional boxes of fish to sell in her fish-vending business.

Junith has been in this business for 21 years. Junith earns additional income from raising pigs.

Junith has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional boxes of fish to sell.

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha is 51 years old and married with four children, two of whom are in school. Editha works very hard to provide for them.

Editha runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 8,000 loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell like soap, shampoo, canned goods, milk, sugar, etc..

Editha has been in this business for 10 years. 

In the future Editha would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell like soap, shampoo, canned goods, milk, and sugar.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth dreams of working in the tourism industry. Elizabeth was accepted into the Universidad Mayor de san Andrés and now, with the chance to achieve her dream, she is concerned about affording tuition fees. She plans on graduating in December, 2014, but often there are fees for earning your degree before graduating. Without a loan from Vittana she fears that she will need to defer her graduation. Elizabeth plans on using this loan to cover the cost of her graduation fees. 

In addition to her responsibilities at school, Elizabeth currently works 30 hours a week and earns $10 a day. With a career in business, she expects to earn $25 a day, a substantial increase from before. Unfortunately, Elizabeth's parents never had the opportunity to complete their high school education. Without the opportunity for a higher degree, her parents never had the chance to move up. Growing up, finances were always tight. 

As the youngest of six, with one older sibling attending college already, Elizabeth is unsure how she will be able to finance her education on her own without the assistance of a Vittana loan.

loans.use: to pay for graduation fees.

loans.name: Milenka

texts.en:
Becoming a professional has always been Milenka's dream. To achieve her goal, Milenka has enrolled in the Universidad Mayor De San Andrés. She expects to graduate in October, 2015, but without a loan, she is unsure how she will be able to continue affording her education. She says that her alternative would be to take time off from school to work and save money until she could return. Milenka says that it is important to her to graduate on time so she can enter into the job market as soon as possible. With this loan, Milenka plans on purchasing her much needed textbooks and school supplies. With the proper books, Milenka feels she will be able to study more effectively and earn better grades. 

In addition to her responsibilities at school, Milenka currently works 30 hours a week in sales and earns $6 a day. With a degree in social work, she expects to earn $10 a day. Milenka's parents were never able to complete their primary education. For her family of five, finances have always been tight. With two other siblings, Milenka is unsure how she will be able to finance her education on her own without the assistance of a Vittana loan. Milenka's father's salary from his job as a small business owner is the family's primary source of income.

loans.use: to pay for books.

loans.name: Claudia Jimena

texts.en:
Claudia has always dreamed of becoming a professional in business. To achieve her goal, Claudia has enrolled in the Universidad San Fransisco Xavier. She plans on graduating in December, 2013, but without a loan from Vittana, she fears that she will need to defer her graduation. With this loan, Claudia plans on purchasing her much needed textbooks and school supplies. With the proper books, Claudia feels she will be able to study more effectively and earn better grades.  

With five older siblings, Claudia is unsure how she will be able to afford her books on her own without the assistance of a Vittana loan.

loans.use: to pay for books.

loans.name: Jose Ronald

texts.es: El Sr. Jose tiene 29 años,  tiene dos hijos que son de las edades de 3 y 5 años, el se dedica a la construcción de puertas y muebles,  tiene su carpintería que se encuentra ubicado en la zona de Barrio Lindo de la ciudad de Santa Cruz se dedica a esta actividad desde hace ya 10 años esta actividad lo aprendió de su padre quien también era carpintero,  este préstamo es su primera secuencia dentro de la institución, el Sr. Jose utilizara  este préstamo  para  la compra de madera para la construcción de puertas , su razón para solicitar este préstamo es la falta de capital para la compra de este material de trabajo, ya que sin esto no podría realizar puertas,  el Sr. Jose enfrenta retos en su negocio que son salir de la pobreza  va a utilizar los beneficios para mejorar su calidad de vida, ya que esta es su única actividad que le permite mantenerse y mantener a su familia, por este motivo se siente feliz ya agradecido a la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en: José is 29 years old.  He has two children, aged three and five years old. José makes a living building doors and furniture, and has a workshop in the Barrio Lindo area of the city of Santa Cruz.  José has been doing this work for ten years, having learned the trade from his father, also a carpenter.  This loan is José's first with the institution and it will be used to buy wood to make doors.  The reason he is applying for this loan is that he does not have the capital to buy the material himself and, without it, he cannot make doors.  José faces challenges with his business, such as trying to escape poverty.  José will use his profits to improve his quality of life and this is the only work he has to support himself and his family.  He is happy with and grateful to the institution for providing this help.

loans.use: to buy wood to make doors.

loans.name: Sunaryo

texts.en:
The story of Sutriani, daughter of Sunaryo :

I live in Rawajaya village, My house is near the river and rice fields, very quiet. My parents work as hodge (farm laborers), and the income is not enough to fulfill our needs. This loan is very useful for me and my family and can ease the burden of my parents. My home from school is about 2.5 kilometers. I go by bike. In this vocational school I will learn about administrative office because I want to be a secretary. After I graduate from this vocational school, I want to work in a company. In this school I hope I will get much more knowledge. My hobby is reading books. Thank you for this program and for the loan. This program is very helping. 

In the picture are Mr. and Mrs. Sunaryo and their daughter, Sutriani.

loans.use: To pay for education fees at the vocational school.

loans.name: Yohanes

texts.en:
The story of Victor, son of Yohanes :

I live in Bringkeng village, a remote village. My parents work as hodge (farm laborers). My parents don’t have their own field. This loan is very helpful for my parents because this loan will help my parents to fulfill my school fees. 

The distance from my home to school is about 6 kilometers and I go to school by motorcycle. In this school I will learn automotive. I choose the automotive major because I like the machine, and the automotive major is easier to get a job. After I graduate from vocational school, I want to work in the automotive field. I hope in this school I will be a good student and ready to work. 

My hobby is sports. I use my free time to help my parents and to study. This time I will say thank you for this program and thank you so much for loan. This program is very useful and helpful for me and my family to fulfill my school fees. 

In the picture are Mr. and Mrs. Yohanes and their son, Victor.

loans.use: To pay for education fees at the vocational school.

loans.name: Razia

texts.en:
Razia is a 35-year-old mother of four children. Her three children go to school, and are so talented that she wants to provide them with higher education. Therefore, she does a lot of hard work to earn income for savings. For example, she does tailoring work at home like sewing clothing for her relatives and ladies in her neighborhood. Nowadays, her sewing machine is out of order and cannot be repaired. She wants to buy a new sewing machine to continue  her business.

Therefore, Razia requested a loan to buy a new sewing machine so that she can sew cloths and save more for her children's higher education in the future. Her husband is a salesman and his whole income is spent on household expenses. Razia is very thankful to Kiva and to its field partner BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine.

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma is a resident of Garcia-Hernandez, Bohol. She is 53 years old and married with eight children ages 13 to 34. Wilma has been engaged in farming tomatoes for 14 years now. She is asking for a loan of 6,000 PHP to buy fertilizer and seedlings and to pay for the labor of the hired help. Her business earns an average income of 4,000 PHP per month, and for Wilma this helps in making both ends meet for her big family.

Wilma is optimistic about the impact of her loan. It will continue to serve her family nutritious food, pay school fees for her children and allow business expansion. In the future, she hopes to have more land to cultivate to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seedlings and to pay for the labor of the hired help.

loans.name: Flor

texts.en:
Flor is 60 years old and married with two children. She works very hard to provide for them.

Flor runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 5,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell like canned goods, milk, sugar, shampoo, noodles, etc. Flor has been in this business for 33 years.

In the future, Flor would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell like canned goods, milk, sugar, shampoo, noodles, etc.

loans.name: Turimin

texts.en:
The story of Andi, son of Turimin :

I live in Karyamekar Bojong village, part of the Kawunganten district. My life is very simple. My parent work as laborers. In the harvest season, we reap the rice; in the fish season, we search for the fishes. 

This loan is very helpful for my continuing education, and it can ease the burden of my parents. The distance from my home to school is about 1 kilometer and I go to school by bus. In this vocational school, I will learn automotive, because automotive is my favorite subject and hobby. After I graduate from this school, I want to work at an automobile assembly factory. Usually I use my free time to take a rest and study. Thank you so much for the loan from the Kiva program. This program is very helpful. 

In the picture are Mr. and Mrs. Turimin and their son, Andi.

loans.use: To pay for education fees at the vocational school.

loans.name: Sharafaddin

texts.en:
Sharafaddin is a 60-year-old married father of 5 kids.  His wife is a housewife.  He is a popular merchant in his hometown, because his shop is situated in the center of town. It has already been 20 years since he started selling food products. His profit from this business is about 150 AZN a month. He sells food products such as macaroni, rice, candies, cookies, sugar, and beverages in his shop. His son also helps him with this business. 

The profit he gains is not enough to reinvest into his business to cover his customers` demands. For this reason he is suffering. His shop is the family's main source of income, and his profit is used for their needs.  Sharafaddin would like to increase his sales and invest additional capital. He applied for a 1,800 AZN loan for this purpose. He will purchase additional food products and diversify. This will be his 6th loan and he has a good credit history.

loans.use: to increase his sales and invest additional capital into his shop.

loans.name: Shamama

texts.en:
Shamama is a 37-year-old mother of two kids. She sells stationery in her shop. She has selling experience from the past 10 years. Previously she used to sell different products in her shop, but now she is focused only on selling items for schoolchildren and students. Shamama is running the business with the support of her husband. She has a shop in the central bazaar. 

She has good sales due to her location near schools and other educational centers. Soon, in September when schools open, more school items are going to be purchased. She has taken 2 loans from AqroInvest previously. Now she requires a loan of 2,000 AZN. With this money she plans to purchase more items for the new semester, when pupils and students return to attend schools and colleges.

loans.use: to purchase more items for the new semester, when pupils and students return to attend schools and colleges.

loans.name: Hadi

texts.en:
This is the story of Agus, son of Hadi:

I live near from the rice field. My father works as a fisherman and a farmer. However, although the harvest season comes, it’s not enough for school fees. And my mother sells jamu (herbal Javanese medicine) by walking around the village. This loan is very helpful for me and my family to fulfill the needs of my school fees. 

The distance of school from my home about 1 kilometer, and I go to school by walking. In this school I will learn about accountancy. I choose the accounting major because for a long time I have loved this major. I want to work at a company. I hope I can get more useful knowledge for my future. My hobby is reading. Thank you a lot for the loan. This loan is very useful for me.

 In this picture are Mr. and Mrs. Hadi and their son, Agus.

loans.use: To pay for education fees at the vocational school.

loans.name: Misan

texts.en:
